definitions.definition: living or growing in natural conditions; not kept in a house or on a farm

examples.text: **wild animals/birds/flowers**
wild salmon
wild mushrooms/rice
The plants grow wild along the banks of rivers.
Their aim is to document wild populations of fast-disappearing species.
a wild boar
The dogs live wild on the streets.
The flowers grow wild in the mountains.
a wild rabbit
wild strawberries

definitions.definition: in its natural state; not changed by people

examples.text: the destruction of forests and other wild lands
wild moorland
The island is a wild and lonely place.
This is truly wild and unspoilt countryside.
The boy is wild and completely out of control.
He had a wild look in his eyes.
a woman with wild hair
wild mood swings
There is a wild side to him.
Her hair was rather wild.
The band has a reputation for wild behaviour.
The crowd **went wild**.
It makes me wild *(= very angry)* to see such waste.
Everything about her drove him wild *(= made him like her very much)*.
wild laughter/celebrations
The couple were dancing with wild abandon.
When the band appeared, the crowd went wild.
The crowd was wild with excitement.
It's the story of a wild and romantic love affair.
Nothing could dull the sense of wild excitement that gripped them.
His speech was greeted by wild applause.

definitions.definition: not carefully planned; not sensible or accurate

examples.text: He made a wild guess at the answer.
wild accusations
We had a wild time in New York.
She's totally wild about him.
She was absolutely wild about him.
I'm not wild about the idea.

definitions.definition: affected by storms and strong winds

examples.text: a wild night
The sea was wild.

definitions.definition: far more, better, etc. than you could ever have imagined or hoped for
used to say that something has happened in a way that somebody did not expect at all

examples.text: Never in my wildest dreams did I think I'd meet him again.

definitions.definition: to grow or develop freely without any control

examples.text: The ivy has run wild.
Let your **imagination run wild** and be creative.
I just let my imagination run wild and come up with as many ideas as I can.

definitions.definition: if children or animals run wild, they behave as they like because nobody is controlling them

examples.text: Those boys have been allowed to run wild.
They annoy the neighbours because they let their children run wild.

definitions.definition: to go through a period of wild behaviour while young, especially having a lot of romantic or sexual relationships

examples.text: He wants to leave home, sow his wild oats and learn about life.

definitions.definition: used to say that nothing would persuade somebody to go somewhere or do something they do not want to do

wordOrigin: Old English wilde, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German wild.
